title: 1.Staff Members Exceeding Supervisor Compensation
sqlCode:
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below */

/*

Explanation:

p represents the staff member.
s represents the supervisor of that staff member.
We join the table to itself on supervisorCode = staffCode to link each employee with their supervisor.
The WHERE clause filters only those staff whose payAmount is greater than their supervisor's payAmount.

*/

SELECT
    p.fullname
FROM
         personnel p
    JOIN personnel s ON p.supervisorcode = s.staffcode
WHERE
    p.payamount > s.payamount;
description:
1. Staff Members Exceeding Supervisor Compensation

Level : Easy

Database Schema

Table: Personnel

+------------------+---------+
| Field            | Format  |
+------------------+---------+
| staffCode        | int     |
| fullName         | varchar |
| payAmount        | int     |
| supervisorCode   | int     |
+------------------+---------+

staffCode serves as the primary key (unique identifier field) for this table.

Every record in this table represents a staff member's unique code, complete name, compensation amount, and the unique code of their direct supervisor.

Develop a query to retrieve all personnel whose compensation exceeds that of their direct supervisors.

The output dataset may be arranged in any sequence.

The output structure follows the pattern illustrated in the demonstration below.

Demonstration:

Input Dataset:

Personnel table:

+-----------+----------+-----------+----------------+
| staffCode | fullName | payAmount | supervisorCode |
+-----------+----------+-----------+----------------+
| 105       | Marcus   | 95000     | 203            |
| 147       | Diana    | 72000     | 318            |
| 203       | Rachel   | 88000     | Null           |
| 318       | Kevin    | 110000    | Null           |
+-----------+----------+-----------+----------------+

Expected Output:

+--------------+
| StaffMember  |
+--------------+
| Marcus       |
+--------------+

Explanation: Marcus is the only staff member whose compensation surpasses that of their supervisor.

title: 2.Recurring Contact Addresses
sqlCode:
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below */

SELECT
    address
FROM
    contact
GROUP BY
    address
HAVING
    COUNT(address) > 1;
description:
2. Recurring Contact Addresses

Level : Easy

Database Schema

Table: Contact

+-----------------+---------+
| Column Name     | Type    |
+-----------------+---------+
| contact_id      | int     |
| address         | varchar |
+-----------------+---------+

contact_id serves as the primary key (unique identifier column) for this table.

Every record in this table includes a contact address. All addresses are stored in lowercase format.

Develop a query to identify all contact addresses that appear more than once in the dataset. The address field is guaranteed to contain valid data with no NULL values.

Your result set may be returned in any sequence.

The output structure is demonstrated in the example below.

Example 1:

Input:

Contact table:

+------------+------------------+
| contact_id | address          |
+------------+------------------+
| 205        | mark@tech.io     |
| 318        | sara@venture.net |
| 429        | mark@tech.io     |
+------------+------------------+

Output: 

+------------------+
| Address          |
+------------------+
| mark@tech.io     |
+------------------+

Explanation: The address mark@tech.io occurs in multiple records within the Contact table.

title: 3.Identify Operators With Enhanced Performance Metrics
sqlCode:
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below */


WITH get_driver_in_both AS (
    SELECT
        operator_id
    FROM
        (
            SELECT DISTINCT
                operator_id,
                CASE
                    WHEN EXTRACT(MONTH FROM journey_date) BETWEEN 1 AND 6 THEN
                        'F'
                    ELSE
                        'S'
                END AS check_half
            FROM
                journeys
        )
    WHERE
        check_half = 'F'
    INTERSECT
    SELECT
        operator_id
    FROM
        (
            SELECT DISTINCT
                operator_id,
                CASE
                    WHEN EXTRACT(MONTH FROM journey_date) BETWEEN 1 AND 6 THEN
                        'F'
                    ELSE
                        'S'
                END AS check_half
            FROM
                journeys
        )
    WHERE
        check_half = 'S'
), get_fuel_cal_fuel_efficency AS (
    SELECT
        t.operator_id,
        CASE
            WHEN EXTRACT(MONTH FROM t.journey_date) BETWEEN 1 AND 6 THEN
                'F'
            ELSE
                'S'
        END                             AS check_half,
        t.distance_miles / t.energy_usage AS fuel_cal
    FROM
             journeys t
        JOIN get_driver_in_both b ON t.operator_id = b.operator_id
), efficiency_improvement AS (
    SELECT
        operator_id,
        round(AVG(
            CASE
                WHEN check_half = 'F' THEN
                    fuel_cal
            END
        ),
              2) AS first_half_avg,
        round(AVG(
            CASE
                WHEN check_half = 'S' THEN
                    fuel_cal
            END
        ),
              2) AS second_half_avg,
        AVG(
            CASE
                WHEN check_half = 'S' THEN
                    fuel_cal
            END
        ) - AVG(
            CASE
                WHEN check_half = 'F' THEN
                    fuel_cal
            END
        )      AS efficiency_improvement
    FROM
        get_fuel_cal_fuel_efficency
    GROUP BY
        operator_id
)
SELECT
    a.operator_id,
    a.operator_name,
    e.first_half_avg,
    e.second_half_avg,
    round(e.efficiency_improvement,2) as efficiency_improvement
FROM
         operators a
    JOIN efficiency_improvement e ON a.operator_id = e.operator_id
    where e.second_half_avg > e.first_half_avg
ORDER BY
    e.efficiency_improvement DESC,
    a.operator_name ASC;
description:
3. Identify Operators with Enhanced Performance Metrics

Medium

Database Schema

Database Schema

Table: operators

+---------------+---------+
| Column Name   | Type    |
+---------------+---------+
| operator_id   | int     |
| operator_name | varchar |
+---------------+---------+

operator_id serves as the unique identifier for this table.

Every record provides details about an individual operator.

Table: journeys

+------------------+---------+
| Column Name      | Type    |
+------------------+---------+
| journey_id       | int     |
| operator_id      | int     |
| journey_date     | date    |
| distance_miles   | decimal |
| energy_usage     | decimal |
+------------------+---------+

journey_id serves as the unique identifier for this table.

Every record captures a journey completed by an operator, documenting the distance covered and energy consumed during that journey.

Develop a query to identify operators whose performance efficiency has shown improvement when comparing their average performance metrics between the initial six months and the latter six months of the year.

Compute performance efficiency as distance_miles / energy_usage for every journey

Initial period: January through June, Latter period: July through December

Include exclusively operators who have completed journeys in both periods of the year

Determine the efficiency enhancement as (latter_period_avg - initial_period_avg)

Round all numerical values to 2 decimal places

Return the result dataset sorted by efficiency enhancement in descending order, followed by operator name in ascending order.

The output structure is demonstrated in the example below.

Example:

Input:

operators table:

+-------------+------------------+
| operator_id | operator_name    |
+-------------+------------------+
| 501         | Marcus Chen      |
| 502         | Linda Rodriguez  |
| 503         | James Anderson   |
| 504         | Sarah Martinez   |
| 505         | Robert Kim       |
+-------------+------------------+

journeys table:

+------------+-------------+--------------+----------------+--------------+
| journey_id | operator_id | journey_date | distance_miles | energy_usage |
+------------+-------------+--------------+----------------+--------------+
| 301        | 501         | 2023-03-08   | 185.7          | 15.8         |
| 302        | 501         | 2023-04-22   | 295.3          | 24.1         |
| 303        | 501         | 2023-09-14   | 220.6          | 16.2         |
| 304        | 501         | 2023-10-28   | 265.4          | 18.3         |
| 305        | 502         | 2023-02-05   | 147.8          | 13.2         |
| 306        | 502         | 2023-05-19   | 368.5          | 32.4         |
| 307        | 502         | 2023-11-07   | 294.7          | 22.1         |
| 308        | 503         | 2023-04-16   | 118.2          | 12.5         |
| 309        | 503         | 2023-06-23   | 132.9          | 13.5         |
| 310        | 504         | 2023-08-26   | 236.1          | 18.9         |
| 311        | 504         | 2023-12-03   | 206.5          | 16.2         |
| 312        | 505         | 2023-03-31   | 162.3          | 16.9         |
+------------+-------------+--------------+----------------+--------------+

Output:

+-------------+------------------+-------------------+--------------------+---------------------------+
| operator_id | operator_name    | initial_period_avg | latter_period_avg | efficiency_enhancement    |
+-------------+------------------+-------------------+--------------------+---------------------------+
| 501         | Marcus Chen      | 12                | 14.06              | 2.06                      |
| 502         | Linda Rodriguez  | 11.29             | 13.33              | 2.05                      |
+-------------+------------------+-------------------+--------------------+---------------------------+

Explanation

Marcus Chen (operator_id = 501)

Initial period journeys (Jan–Jun):
Mar 8: 185.7 ÷ 15.8 = 11.75
Apr 22: 295.3 ÷ 24.1 = 12.25

Initial period average efficiency:
(11.75 + 12.25) ÷ 2 = 12.00

Latter period journeys (Jul–Dec):
Sep 14: 220.6 ÷ 16.2 = 13.62
Oct 28: 265.4 ÷ 18.3 = 14.50

Latter period average efficiency:
(13.62 + 14.50) ÷ 2 = 14.06

Efficiency enhancement:
14.06 − 12.00 = 2.06

Linda Rodriguez (operator_id = 502)

Initial period journeys:
Feb 5: 147.8 ÷ 13.2 = 11.20
May 19: 368.5 ÷ 32.4 = 11.37

Initial period average efficiency:
(11.20 + 11.37) ÷ 2 = 11.29

Latter period journeys:
Nov 7: 294.7 ÷ 22.1 = 13.33

Latter period average efficiency:
13.33

Efficiency enhancement:
13.33 − 11.29 = 2.05

Operators Not Included

  • James Anderson (operator_id = 503): Journeys only in the initial period (Apr, Jun)
  • Sarah Martinez (operator_id = 504): Journeys only in the latter period (Aug, Dec)
  • Robert Kim (operator_id = 505): Journeys only in the initial period (Mar)

The output dataset is arranged by efficiency enhancement in descending order, followed by operator name in ascending order.

title: 3220 Odd And Even Transactions
description:
3530. Odd and Even Transactions

Medium

Table: transactions

+------------------+------+
| Column Name      | Type | 
+------------------+------+
| transaction_id   | int  |
| amount           | int  |
| transaction_date | date |
+------------------+------+
The transactions_id column uniquely identifies each row in this table.
Each row of this table contains the transaction id, amount and transaction date.

Write a solution to find the sum of amounts for odd and even transactions for each day. If there are no odd or even transactions for a specific date, display as 0.

Return the result table ordered by transaction_date in ascending order.

The result format is in the following example.

 

Example:

Input:

transactions table:

+----------------+--------+------------------+
| transaction_id | amount | transaction_date |
+----------------+--------+------------------+
| 1              | 150    | 2024-07-01       |
| 2              | 200    | 2024-07-01       |
| 3              | 75     | 2024-07-01       |
| 4              | 300    | 2024-07-02       |
| 5              | 50     | 2024-07-02       |
| 6              | 120    | 2024-07-03       |
+----------------+--------+------------------+

Output:

+------------------+---------+----------+
| transaction_date | odd_sum | even_sum |
+------------------+---------+----------+
| 2024-07-01       | 75      | 350      |
| 2024-07-02       | 0       | 350      |
| 2024-07-03       | 0       | 120      |
+------------------+---------+----------+

Explanation:

  • For transaction dates:
    • 2024-07-01:
      • Sum of amounts for odd transactions: 75
      • Sum of amounts for even transactions: 150 + 200 = 350
    • 2024-07-02:
      • Sum of amounts for odd transactions: 0
      • Sum of amounts for even transactions: 300 + 50 = 350
    • 2024-07-03:
      • Sum of amounts for odd transactions: 0
      • Sum of amounts for even transactions: 120

Note: The output table is ordered by transaction_date in ascending order.

title: 4.Identify Personnel With Progressive Performance Growth
sqlCode:
/* Write your PL/SQL query statement below */

WITH data AS (
    SELECT
        *
    FROM
        (
            SELECT
                staff_id,
                assessment_date,
                score,
                ROW_NUMBER()
                OVER(PARTITION BY staff_id
                     ORDER BY
                         assessment_date DESC, score DESC
                ) AS rnk_ass_rt,
                COUNT(*)
                OVER(PARTITION BY staff_id
                     ORDER BY
                         staff_id
                ) AS cnt_rd
            FROM
                evaluation_records
        )
    WHERE
            cnt_rd >= 3
        AND rnk_ass_rt <= 3
)
SELECT
    a.staff_id,
    p.full_name,
    score - lead_2 AS growth_metric
FROM
         (
        SELECT
            *
        FROM
            (
                SELECT
                    staff_id,
                    score,
                    LEAD(score, 1)
                    OVER(PARTITION BY staff_id
                         ORDER BY
                             assessment_date DESC
                    ) AS lead_1,
                    LEAD(score, 2)
                    OVER(PARTITION BY staff_id
                         ORDER BY
                             assessment_date DESC
                    ) AS lead_2
                FROM
                    data
            )
        WHERE
            ( score IS NOT NULL
              AND lead_1 IS NOT NULL
              AND lead_2 IS NOT NULL )
            AND ( score > lead_1
                  AND lead_1 > lead_2 )
    ) a
    JOIN personnel p ON a.staff_id = p.staff_id
ORDER BY
    ( score - lead_2 ) DESC,
    p.full_name ASC;
description:
4. Identify Personnel with Progressive Performance Growth

Medium

SQL Schema

Table: personnel

+-------------+---------+
| Column Name | Type    |
+-------------+---------+
| staff_id    | int     |
| full_name   | varchar |
+-------------+---------+

staff_id serves as the primary key for this table.

Each record contains details about a staff member.

Table: evaluation_records

+------------------+------+
| Column Name      | Type |
+------------------+------+
| evaluation_id    | int  |
| staff_id         | int  |
| assessment_date  | date |
| score            | int  |
+------------------+------+

evaluation_id serves as the primary key for this table.

Each record captures a performance evaluation for a staff member. Scores range from 1 to 5, with 5 representing outstanding performance and 1 indicating underperformance.

Compose a query to identify staff members whose performance has demonstrated continuous upward progression across their three most recent evaluations.

A staff member must possess a minimum of 3 evaluations to qualify for consideration

The three most recent evaluations must exhibit strictly ascending scores (each subsequent assessment exceeding the prior one)

Utilize the three latest evaluations determined by assessment_date for each staff member

Compute the growth_metric as the numerical difference between the most recent score and the oldest score within the latest 3 evaluations

Present the result set sorted by growth_metric in descending sequence, followed by full_name in ascending sequence.

The result format is demonstrated in the example below.

Example:

Input:

personnel table:

+----------+-------------------+
| staff_id | full_name         |
+----------+-------------------+
| 203      | Marcus Chen       |
| 417      | Sofia Rodriguez   |
| 528      | Liam O'Connor     |
| 635      | Priya Patel       |
| 749      | James Anderson    |
+----------+-------------------+

evaluation_records table:

+---------------+----------+-----------------+-------+
| evaluation_id | staff_id | assessment_date | score |
+---------------+----------+-----------------+-------+
| 891           | 203      | 2023-02-08      | 1     |
| 892           | 203      | 2023-05-12      | 2     |
| 893           | 203      | 2023-08-19      | 3     |
| 894           | 203      | 2023-11-23      | 4     |
| 895           | 417      | 2023-03-14      | 2     |
| 896           | 417      | 2023-06-18      | 1     |
| 897           | 417      | 2023-09-22      | 3     |
| 898           | 417      | 2023-12-05      | 4     |
| 899           | 528      | 2023-01-25      | 2     |
| 900           | 528      | 2023-04-29      | 3     |
| 901           | 528      | 2023-07-31      | 4     |
| 902           | 528      | 2023-10-28      | 5     |
| 903           | 635      | 2023-02-17      | 3     |
| 904           | 635      | 2023-05-21      | 3     |
| 905           | 635      | 2023-08-24      | 3     |
| 906           | 749      | 2023-03-06      | 4     |
| 907           | 749      | 2023-06-09      | 3     |
+---------------+----------+-----------------+-------+

Output:

+----------+-------------------+---------------+
| staff_id | full_name         | growth_metric |
+----------+-------------------+---------------+
| 417      | Sofia Rodriguez   | 3             |
| 528      | Liam O'Connor     | 2             |
| 203      | Marcus Chen       | 2             |
+----------+-------------------+---------------+

Explanation:

Marcus Chen (staff_id = 203):

  • Total evaluations: 4
  • All evaluation dates and scores:
    • 2023-02-08: score = 1
    • 2023-05-12: score = 2
    • 2023-08-19: score = 3
    • 2023-11-23: score = 4
  • Latest 3 evaluations (by assessment_date):
    • 1st oldest: 2023-05-12 with score = 2
    • 2nd: 2023-08-19 with score = 3
    • 3rd most recent: 2023-11-23 with score = 4
  • Checking strict progression: 2 < 3 < 4 ✓ (strictly increasing)
  • Growth metric calculation: 4 - 2 = 2
  • Result: INCLUDED

Sofia Rodriguez (staff_id = 417):

  • Total evaluations: 4
  • All evaluation dates and scores:
    • 2023-03-14: score = 2
    • 2023-06-18: score = 1
    • 2023-09-22: score = 3
    • 2023-12-05: score = 4
  • Latest 3 evaluations (by assessment_date):
    • 1st oldest: 2023-06-18 with score = 1
    • 2nd: 2023-09-22 with score = 3
    • 3rd most recent: 2023-12-05 with score = 4
  • Checking strict progression: 1 < 3 < 4 ✓ (strictly increasing)
  • Growth metric calculation: 4 - 1 = 3
  • Result: INCLUDED

Liam O'Connor (staff_id = 528):

  • Total evaluations: 4
  • All evaluation dates and scores:
    • 2023-01-25: score = 2
    • 2023-04-29: score = 3
    • 2023-07-31: score = 4
    • 2023-10-28: score = 5
  • Latest 3 evaluations (by assessment_date):
    • 1st oldest: 2023-04-29 with score = 3
    • 2nd: 2023-07-31 with score = 4
    • 3rd most recent: 2023-10-28 with score = 5
  • Checking strict progression: 3 < 4 < 5 ✓ (strictly increasing)
  • Growth metric calculation: 5 - 3 = 2
  • Result: INCLUDED

Priya Patel (staff_id = 635):

  • Total evaluations: 3
  • All evaluation dates and scores:
    • 2023-02-17: score = 3
    • 2023-05-21: score = 3
    • 2023-08-24: score = 3
  • Latest 3 evaluations (by assessment_date):
    • 1st oldest: 2023-02-17 with score = 3
    • 2nd: 2023-05-21 with score = 3
    • 3rd most recent: 2023-08-24 with score = 3
  • Checking strict progression: 3 = 3 = 3 ✗ (NOT strictly increasing, no progression)
  • Result: EXCLUDED (scores are equal, not increasing)

James Anderson (staff_id = 749):

  • Total evaluations: 2
  • All evaluation dates and scores:
    • 2023-03-06: score = 4
    • 2023-06-09: score = 3
  • Has only 2 evaluations, but requirement is minimum of 3 evaluations
  • Result: EXCLUDED (insufficient evaluation records)

Final Result Ordering:

  • Sort by growth_metric descending: Sofia Rodriguez (3), then Liam O'Connor (2) and Marcus Chen (2)
  • For tied growth_metric values (both 2), sort by full_name ascending: "Liam O'Connor" comes before "Marcus Chen" alphabetically
  • Final order: Sofia Rodriguez (3), Liam O'Connor (2), Marcus Chen (2)
